topic.title: [MEGA POST] Holocene Extinction  - What is the latest specie to have gone extinct this week?
topic.body:
I guess the more dramatic question, is how many already this year? I don't know... 1000? more? that's interesting how it's all about CO2 (plant food) meanwhile some of those species have seen ice ages, etc, and have now come to their extinctions, and not due to CO2... 

but if the hitlerian youth, excuse me, the autistic lead low iq , only censored information, only care about co2, demands, it is still not a reason to let those no iq let the extinction happen.

"The Holocene extinction, otherwise referred to as the sixth mass extinction or Anthropocene extinction, is an ongoing extinction event of species during the present Holocene epoch (with the more recent time sometimes called Anthropocene) as a result of human activity.[3][4][5] The included extinctions span numerous families of plants[6] and animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fishes and invertebrates. With widespread degradation of highly biodiverse habitats such as coral reefs and rainforests, as well as other areas, the vast majority of these extinctions are thought to be undocumented, as the species are undiscovered at the time of their extinction, or no one has yet discovered their extinction. The current rate of extinction of species is estimated at 100 to 1,000 times higher than natural background extinction rates.[4][7][8][9][10][11]"

at least the next King of England and all possession thereoff is aware of this really serious issue... I hope everyone in the uk (and I mean all those who will never be subject of the king, from birds to roaches) will be able to make it... and no co2 isn't their problem at all...

A question about Moskow, capital of the russian federation : is it safe to park a bike without a triple lock, removing the chair, and even the front wheel? Second, I have the impression that 

Moskow is a yuge city...

I mean that the building may look small in size, but it's just that they are proportionnate, meaning that they are yuge, like a long time to walk a block.

secondly, I imagine that the soviet blocks apparements have big ceilings? and are well insulated from inner noise?

3. I believe there are a lot of public space, park to walk, kids play ground, all over the city and around, all of this artifical, and untold expanse of wilderness not that far... (the last bus stop before the wild).

5. 1 Netherland :

"The official legislative changes to introduce this policy took place in 1976. In 1980, the Dutch government finally announced it would discontinue prosecuting cannabis and hashish offenses under certain circumstances."

Life expectancy : 

    The current life expectancy for Netherlands in 2021 is 82.49 years, a 0.17% increase from 2020.
    The life expectancy for Netherlands in 2020 was 82.35 years, a 0.18% increase from 2019.
    The life expectancy for Netherlands in 2019 was 82.20 years, a 0.18% increase from 2018.
    The life expectancy for Netherlands in 2018 was 82.06 years, a 0.18% increase from 2017.

In 1976 it was 74.75 according to https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/NLD/netherlands/life-expectancy  

Mooniies :

Netherlands GDP per capita 

    Netherlands gdp per capita for 2019 was $52,331, a 1.34% decline from 2018.
    Netherlands gdp per capita for 2018 was $53,045, a 8.98% increase from 2017.
    Netherlands gdp per capita for 2017 was $48,675, a 5.8% increase from 2016.
    Netherlands gdp per capita for 2016 was $46,008, a 1.84% increase from 2015.

In 1976 it was $7,926 according to https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/NLD/netherlands/gdp-per-capita

For further discussion : https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/NLD/netherlands/economic-growth-rate

2 Portugal 

"In 1999, after the approval of a national strategy to combat drugs and drug addiction, the Portuguese government issued Law No. 30/2000, which decriminalized the acquisition, possession, and use of specified plants, substances, or preparations for a person's own consumption, and turned such conduct into misdemeanors."


    The current life expectancy for Portugal in 2021 is 82.29 years, a 0.22% increase from 2020.
    The life expectancy for Portugal in 2020 was 82.11 years, a 0.22% increase from 2019.
    The life expectancy for Portugal in 2019 was 81.93 years, a 0.22% increase from 2018.
    The life expectancy for Portugal in 2018 was 81.75 years, a 0.28% increase from 2017.


in 2000 76.63

    Portugal gdp per capita for 2017 was $21,490, a 7.57% increase from 2016.
    Portugal gdp per capita for 2016 was $19,978, a 3.83% increase from 2015.


in 2000 $11,725

3 Uruguay :

"Cannabis is legal in Uruguay, and is one of the most widely used drugs in the nation. President Jose Mujica signed legislation to legalize recreational cannabis in December 2013, making Uruguay the first country in the modern era to legalize cannabis."


    The current life expectancy for Uruguay in 2021 is 78.13 years, a 0.19% increase from 2020.
    The life expectancy for Uruguay in 2020 was 77.99 years, a 0.19% increase from 2019.
    The life expectancy for Uruguay in 2019 was 77.84 years, a 0.19% increase from 2018.
    The life expectancy for Uruguay in 2018 was 77.69 years, a 0.17% increase from 2017.

in 2013 it was 77.05

GDP per capita.

    Uruguay gdp per capita for 2019 was $16,190, a 6.3% decline from 2018.
    Uruguay gdp per capita for 2018 was $17,278, a 0.26% decline from 2017.
    Uruguay gdp per capita for 2017 was $17,322, a 12.58% increase from 2016.
    Uruguay gdp per capita for 2016 was $15,387, a 1.45% decline from 2015.

in 2013 it was $16,974

> [jpeer](#comment_1_1JMgYVF1m2q5WmTzMt38fheBfogLL3Uwq8): i like turtles

Alligator snapping turtles have been around at least 20 million years, and their jaws and ridges are similar to the skin of an alligator. The interesting thing about them is that these turtles are one ferocious reptiles with strong beak-like jaw and large claws.

With the super strong jaws, these alligator snapping turtles have one of the strongest bites of any animals. Their jaws are capable of crushing our bones, and we should never handle them in the wild. That is why there have been reported cases where humans fingers have been cleanly bitten off by them. 

This species is now threatened, and there are fewer than 900 of them in wild nowadays.
